location: The Grecian camp. Lists set out.

lines.text: Enter AJAX, armed AGAMEMNON, ACHILLES, PATROCLUS, MENELAUS, ULYSSES, NESTOR, and others

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: Here art thou in appointment fresh and fair, Anticipating time with starting courage. Give with thy trumpet a loud note to Troy, Thou dreadful Ajax that the appalled air May pierce the head of the great combatant And hale him hither.

lines.speaker: ajax
lines.text: Thou, trumpet, theres my purse. Now crack thy lungs, and split thy brazen pipe: Blow, villain, till thy sphered bias cheek Outswell the colic of puffd Aquilon: Come, stretch thy chest and let thy eyes spout blood Thou blowst for Hector.
Trumpet sounds

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: No trumpet answers.

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: Tis but early days.

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: Is not yond Diomed, with Calchas daughter

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: Tis he, I ken the manner of his gait He rises on the toe: that spirit of his In aspiration lifts him from the earth.
Enter DIOMEDES, with CRESSIDA

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: Is this the Lady Cressid

lines.speaker: diomedes
lines.text: Even she.

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: Most dearly welcome to the Greeks, sweet lady.

lines.speaker: nestor
lines.text: Our general doth salute you with a kiss.

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: Yet is the kindness but particular Twere better she were kissd in general.

lines.speaker: nestor
lines.text: And very courtly counsel: Ill begin. So much for Nestor.

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: Ill take what winter from your lips, fair lady: Achilles bids you welcome.

lines.speaker: menelaus
lines.text: I had good argument for kissing once.

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: But thats no argument for kissing now For this poppd Paris in his hardiment, And parted thus you and your argument.

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: O deadly gall, and theme of all our scorns! For which we lose our heads to gild his horns.

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: The first was Menelaus kiss this, mine: Patroclus kisses you.

lines.speaker: menelaus
lines.text: O, this is trim!

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: Paris and I kiss evermore for him.

lines.speaker: menelaus
lines.text: Ill have my kiss, sir. Lady, by your leave.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: In kissing, do you render or receive

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: Both take and give.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Ill make my match to live, The kiss you take is better than you give Therefore no kiss.

lines.speaker: menelaus
lines.text: Ill give you boot, Ill give you three for one.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Youre an odd man give even or give none.

lines.speaker: menelaus
lines.text: An odd man, lady! every man is odd.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: No, Paris is not for you know tis true, That you are odd, and he is even with you.

lines.speaker: menelaus
lines.text: You fillip me o the head.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: No, Ill be sworn.

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: It were no match, your nail against his horn. May I, sweet lady, beg a kiss of you

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: You may.

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: I do desire it.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Why, beg, then.

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: Why then for Venus sake, give me a kiss, When Helen is a maid again, and his.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: I am your debtor, claim it when tis due.

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: Nevers my day, and then a kiss of you.

lines.speaker: diomedes
lines.text: Lady, a word: Ill bring you to your father.
Exit with CRESSIDA

lines.speaker: nestor
lines.text: A woman of quick sense.

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: Fie, fie upon her! Theres language in her eye, her cheek, her lip, Nay, her foot speaks her wanton spirits look out At every joint and motive of her body. O, these encounterers, so glib of tongue, That give accosting welcome ere it comes, And wide unclasp the tables of their thoughts To every ticklish reader! set them down For sluttish spoils of opportunity And daughters of the game.
Trumpet within

lines.speaker: all
lines.text: The Trojans trumpet.

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: Yonder comes the troop. Enter HECTOR, armed AENEAS, TROILUS, and other Trojans, with Attendants

lines.speaker: aeneas
lines.text: Hail, all you state of Greece! what shall be done To him that victory commands or do you purpose A victor shall be known will you the knights Shall to the edge of all extremity Pursue each other, or shall be divided By any voice or order of the field Hector bade ask.

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: Which way would Hector have it

lines.speaker: aeneas
lines.text: He cares not hell obey conditions.

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: Tis done like Hector but securely done, A little proudly, and great deal misprizing The knight opposed.

lines.speaker: aeneas
lines.text: If not Achilles, sir, What is your name

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: If not Achilles, nothing.

lines.speaker: aeneas
lines.text: Therefore Achilles: but, whateer, know this: In the extremity of great and little, Valour and pride excel themselves in Hector The one almost as infinite as all, The other blank as nothing. Weigh him well, And that which looks like pride is courtesy. This Ajax is half made of Hectors blood: In love whereof, half Hector stays at home Half heart, half hand, half Hector comes to seek This blended knight, half Trojan and half Greek.

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: A maiden battle, then O, I perceive you.
Reenter DIOMEDES

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: Here is Sir Diomed. Go, gentle knight, Stand by our Ajax: as you and Lord AEneas Consent upon the order of their fight, So be it either to the uttermost, Or else a breath: the combatants being kin Half stints their strife before their strokes begin.
AJAX and HECTOR enter the lists

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: They are opposed already.

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: What Trojan is that same that looks so heavy

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: The youngest son of Priam, a true knight, Not yet mature, yet matchless, firm of word, Speaking in deeds and deedless in his tongue Not soon provoked nor being provoked soon calmd: His heart and hand both open and both free For what he has he gives, what thinks he shows Yet gives he not till judgment guide his bounty, Nor dignifies an impure thought with breath Manly as Hector, but more dangerous For Hector in his blaze of wrath subscribes To tender objects, but he in heat of action Is more vindicative than jealous love: They call him Troilus, and on him erect A second hope, as fairly built as Hector. Thus says AEneas one that knows the youth Even to his inches, and with private soul Did in great Ilion thus translate him to me.
Alarum. Hector and Ajax fight

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: They are in action.

lines.speaker: nestor
lines.text: Now, Ajax, hold thine own!

lines.speaker: troilus
lines.text: Hector, thou sleepst Awake thee!

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: His blows are well disposed: there, Ajax!

lines.speaker: diomedes
lines.text: You must no more.
Trumpets cease

lines.speaker: aeneas
lines.text: Princes, enough, so please you.

lines.speaker: ajax
lines.text: I am not warm yet let us fight again.

lines.speaker: diomedes
lines.text: As Hector pleases.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: Why, then will I no more: Thou art, great lord, my fathers sisters son, A cousingerman to great Priams seed The obligation of our blood forbids A gory emulation twixt us twain: Were thy commixtion Greek and Trojan so That thou couldst say This hand is Grecian all, And this is Trojan the sinews of this leg All Greek, and this all Troy my mothers blood Runs on the dexter cheek, and this sinister Bounds in my fathers by Jove multipotent, Thou shouldst not bear from me a Greekish member Wherein my sword had not impressure made Of our rank feud: but the just gods gainsay That any drop thou borrowdst from thy mother, My sacred aunt, should by my mortal sword Be draind! Let me embrace thee, Ajax: By him that thunders, thou hast lusty arms Hector would have them fall upon him thus: Cousin, all honour to thee!

lines.speaker: ajax
lines.text: I thank thee, Hector Thou art too gentle and too free a man: I came to kill thee, cousin, and bear hence A great addition earned in thy death.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: Not Neoptolemus so mirable, On whose bright crest Fame with her loudst Oyes Cries This is he, could promise to himself A thought of added honour torn from Hector.

lines.speaker: aeneas
lines.text: There is expectance here from both the sides, What further you will do.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: Well answer it The issue is embracement: Ajax, farewell.

lines.speaker: ajax
lines.text: If I might in entreaties find success As seld I have the chanceI would desire My famous cousin to our Grecian tents.

lines.speaker: diomedes
lines.text: Tis Agamemnons wish, and great Achilles Doth long to see unarmd the valiant Hector.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: AEneas, call my brother Troilus to me, And signify this loving interview To the expecters of our Trojan part Desire them home. Give me thy hand, my cousin I will go eat with thee and see your knights.

lines.speaker: ajax
lines.text: Great Agamemnon comes to meet us here.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: The worthiest of them tell me name by name But for Achilles, mine own searching eyes Shall find him by his large and portly size.

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: Worthy of arms! as welcome as to one That would be rid of such an enemy But thats no welcome: understand more clear, Whats past and whats to come is strewd with husks And formless ruin of oblivion But in this extant moment, faith and troth, Straind purely from all hollow biasdrawing, Bids thee, with most divine integrity, From heart of very heart, great Hector, welcome.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: I thank thee, most imperious Agamemnon.

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: [To TROILUS]  My wellfamed lord of Troy, no less to you.

lines.speaker: menelaus
lines.text: Let me confirm my princely brothers greeting: You brace of warlike brothers, welcome hither.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: Who must we answer

lines.speaker: aeneas
lines.text: The noble Menelaus.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: O, you, my lord by Mars his gauntlet, thanks! Mock not, that I affect the untraded oath Your quondam wife swears still by Venus glove: Shes well, but bade me not commend her to you.

lines.speaker: menelaus
lines.text: Name her not now, sir shes a deadly theme.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: O, pardon I offend.

lines.speaker: nestor
lines.text: I have, thou gallant Trojan, seen thee oft Labouring for destiny make cruel way Through ranks of Greekish youth, and I have seen thee, As hot as Perseus, spur thy Phrygian steed, Despising many forfeits and subduements, When thou hast hung thy advanced sword i the air, Not letting it decline on the declined, That I have said to some my standers by Lo, Jupiter is yonder, dealing life! And I have seen thee pause and take thy breath, When that a ring of Greeks have hemmd thee in, Like an Olympian wrestling: this have I seen But this thy countenance, still lockd in steel, I never saw till now. I knew thy grandsire, And once fought with him: he was a soldier good But, by great Mars, the captain of us all, Never saw like thee. Let an old man embrace thee And, worthy warrior, welcome to our tents.

lines.speaker: aeneas
lines.text: Tis the old Nestor.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: Let me embrace thee, good old chronicle, That hast so long walkd hand in hand with time: Most reverend Nestor, I am glad to clasp thee.

lines.speaker: nestor
lines.text: I would my arms could match thee in contention, As they contend with thee in courtesy.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: I would they could.

lines.speaker: nestor
lines.text: Ha! By this white beard, Ild fight with thee tomorrow. Well, welcome, welcome! I have seen the time.

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: I wonder now how yonder city stands When we have here her base and pillar by us.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: I know your favour, Lord Ulysses, well. Ah, sir, theres many a Greek and Trojan dead, Since first I saw yourself and Diomed In Ilion, on your Greekish embassy.

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: Sir, I foretold you then what would ensue: My prophecy is but half his journey yet For yonder walls, that pertly front your town, Yond towers, whose wanton tops do buss the clouds, Must kiss their own feet.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: I must not believe you: There they stand yet, and modestly I think, The fall of every Phrygian stone will cost A drop of Grecian blood: the end crowns all, And that old common arbitrator, Time, Will one day end it.

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: So to him we leave it. Most gentle and most valiant Hector, welcome: After the general, I beseech you next To feast with me and see me at my tent.

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: I shall forestall thee, Lord Ulysses, thou! Now, Hector, I have fed mine eyes on thee I have with exact view perused thee, Hector, And quoted joint by joint.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: Is this Achilles

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: I am Achilles.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: Stand fair, I pray thee: let me look on thee.

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: Behold thy fill.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: Nay, I have done already.

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: Thou art too brief: I will the second time, As I would buy thee, view thee limb by limb.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: O, like a book of sport thoult read me oer But theres more in me than thou understandst. Why dost thou so oppress me with thine eye

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: Tell me, you heavens, in which part of his body Shall I destroy him whether there, or there, or there That I may give the local wound a name And make distinct the very breach whereout Hectors great spirit flew: answer me, heavens!

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: It would discredit the blest gods, proud man, To answer such a question: stand again: Thinkst thou to catch my life so pleasantly As to prenominate in nice conjecture Where thou wilt hit me dead

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: I tell thee, yea.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: Wert thou an oracle to tell me so, Id not believe thee. Henceforth guard thee well For Ill not kill thee there, nor there, nor there But, by the forge that stithied Mars his helm, Ill kill thee every where, yea, oer and oer. You wisest Grecians, pardon me this brag His insolence draws folly from my lips But Ill endeavour deeds to match these words, Or may I never

lines.speaker: ajax
lines.text: Do not chafe thee, cousin: And you, Achilles, let these threats alone, Till accident or purpose bring you tot: You may have every day enough of Hector If you have stomach the general state, I fear, Can scarce entreat you to be odd with him.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: I pray you, let us see you in the field: We have had pelting wars, since you refused The Grecians cause.

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: Dost thou entreat me, Hector Tomorrow do I meet thee, fell as death Tonight all friends.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: Thy hand upon that match.

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: First, all you peers of Greece, go to my tent There in the full convive we: afterwards, As Hectors leisure and your bounties shall Concur together, severally entreat him. Beat loud the tabourines, let the trumpets blow, That this great soldier may his welcome know.
Exeunt all except TROILUS and ULYSSES

lines.speaker: troilus
lines.text: My Lord Ulysses, tell me, I beseech you, In what place of the field doth Calchas keep

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: At Menelaus tent, most princely Troilus: There Diomed doth feast with him tonight Who neither looks upon the heaven nor earth, But gives all gaze and bent of amorous view On the fair Cressid.

lines.speaker: troilus
lines.text: Shall sweet lord, be bound to you so much, After we part from Agamemnons tent, To bring me thither

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: You shall command me, sir. As gentle tell me, of what honour was This Cressida in Troy Had she no lover there That wails her absence

lines.speaker: troilus
lines.text: O, sir, to such as boasting show their scars A mock is due. Will you walk on, my lord She was beloved, she loved she is, and doth: But still sweet love is food for fortunes tooth.
Exeunt
